item.title: Cookies
item.description:
What are cookies?

Cookies are small text files that the websites visited send to the user's device (computer, tablet, smartphone, notebook), where they are stored and then retransmitted to the same websites upon the next visit. They are used to perform computer authentications, session monitoring, and storing information about the sites. Through cookies, navigation can also be monitored, data on preferences, habits, and personal choices can be collected, allowing the reconstruction of detailed consumer profiles.

item.title: Research
item.description:
Research, along with training, is a key aspect of the CASA-project.

The CASA-project also include the longitudinal collection of epidemiological data of a cohort of patients with HIV infection taking ART. The systematic collection of epidemiological data is intended to assess the longitudinal effectiveness of ART as used in Ethiopia in a real-world setting. Data on demographic and clinical characteristics, medical care and clinical and laboratory outcomes are routinely collected on HIV-infected patients receiving ART at each participating HF during . Data reports are periodically produced.

item.title: Participating Health Facilities
item.description: The Health Facilities (HFs) participating in the CASA-Ethiopia project are situated  in urban and rural area as well. They include two Health Centers (HCs) and five Hospitals. The aim of CASA-project is also to stimulate debate and discussion among participants in order to create a collaborative networking among the HFs participating in the project.  Sharing and discussion of the research results is indeed  a crucial part for improving daily clinical practice.

item.title: About CASA – Ethiopia
item.description:
The first nation to be involved in the CASA – project is Ethiopia also by virtue of the historical relations between Italy and that nation. The Italian contribution has, indeed, proved one of the most significant in the ambit of the fight against poverty in Ethiopia, involving sectors of crucial importance, such as, education, energy and health services organization.

Communicable diseases (CDs), including tuberculosis (TB), malaria, HIV/AIDS, respiratory infections, diarrheal diseases and nutritional deficiencies contribute to the high disease burden in Ethiopia. HIV/AIDS is still one of the main health challenges to be faced. Although HIV prevalence is not very high, and the country recently experienced a major reduction in new HIV infections, it still has a large number of people living with HIV (PLWH): in 2014 (latest estimated data) the adult prevalence was 1.2 % [1.0%-1.5%], with an estimated 730,000 [600,000-970,000] PLHIV.

item.title: Partnership
item.description:
The CASA-project is a partnership among three International bodies:

  1. Tigray Health Bureau (THB), Tigray, Ethiopia
  2. Mekelle University (MU), Tigray, Ethiopia
  3. Istituto Superiore di Sanità (ISS), Rome, Italy

The THB is the public structure competent for planning and management of health needs at regional level. The THB is the main Ethiopian institution of reference for the CASA project, having full ownership of the project.

item.title: Patients’ Associations
item.description:
The CASA–project involves collaboration with the Network of Charitable Societies of HIV Positives in Tigray (TNEP+). TNEP+ is a Associations’ Network of people living with HIV in Tigray Region. It was established in March 2009 at Mekelle city and was registered in June 2010 at Federal Charities and Societies Agency.

The main role of TNEP+  is to actively contribute to improving patients retention in care and adherence to therapy. A close collaboration between TNEP+ members and the health facilities involved in the CASA-project has been scheduled during the project.

item.title: Training
item.description:
Knowledge transfer is an essential component of CASA – project.

The training activities fall into two main typologies:

  1. On-site training courses.
  2. Participation in international meetings/conferences/courses:

    1. On-site training courses: a significant component of the training activities is based on training tools ((booklets, E-learning platform, work-shops).  After each training-course, examination sessions are organized to evaluate the benefits achieved by learners and select the future trainers (a train the trainer approach).
    2. This project also includes short periods of training to be carried outside of Tigray. Participating in international meetings or congresses or courses represents an important activity aimed to improve the skill of local health workers and to stimulate international networking as well.
